Article 4 of the [[Bunreacht na hÃireann|Irish constitution]] adopted in 1937 provides that: "The name of the state is Ãire, or, in the English language, ''Ireland''."<ref>"[http://www.taoiseach.gov.ie/attached_files/html%20files/Constitution%20of%20Ireland%20(Eng)Nov2004.htm Bunreacht Na Ãireann]". Office of the Houses of the Oireachtas. Retrieved on 14 March 2007</ref> The Constitution's English-language [[Irish Constitution#Preamble (full text)|preamble]] also described the population as "We, the people of Ãire". The ''[[Republic of Ireland Act]]'' enacted in 1948 makes clear that the "Republic of Ireland" is a description and not a name of the state. Ireland (in English) and Ãire (in Irish) remain its two official names. Article 8 states that both Irish and English are the official languages of the state with Irish designated as the "national" and "first official" language. "Ãire" has to some extent passed out of everyday conversation and literature.
